awd_titl_txt: SBE: Small: Cybersecurity risks of dynamic, two-way distributed electricity markets
awd_abstract_narration:
The U.S. electric grid is being transformed from a one-way channel delivering electricity from central power plants to customers at set prices, toward a distributed grid with two-way flows of information and electricity and dynamic distributed markets. The benefits of creating distributed markets for electricity are potentially great. Consumers can participate as buyers and sellers in these markets, utilities can reduce costly peak electricity load and risk of outages, and firms can be rewarded for innovation. However, along with these potential benefits come significant cybersecurity and privacy risks. Participants in distribution-level markets may be technically unsophisticated and use energy management and communications systems that do not provide high levels of security. The potential cost of a security breach that overloads or shuts down large areas of critical infrastructure is immense. This research identifies potential security and privacy risks associated with distributed electricity markets, measures to provide an acceptable level of risk, and trade-offs between risk reduction and performance of distributed markets. The results will provide guidance to utilities, regulators and other participants in designing effective and robust market structures with necessary security and privacy protection.

The research is multidisciplinary, including economics, computer science and public policy. It employs an innovative mix of research methods, including interviews, modeling of market structures, simulations using real world electricity use data, modeling of data flows, and security threat analysis. A discrete event simulation framework is used to model interacting agents that will comprise distributed electricity markets and to estimate a cost function for the relative welfare cost of given grid topologies and market policies. A software simulator is constructed and tested using real electricity use data to vary parameters on multiple dimensions and minimize cost. Security attacks are introduced into the simulations to identify impacts on grid stability, market trust and privacy. The use of real world data enables simulation of a wide array of different market structures and interactions with a variety of bidding and response policies on the part of distributed consumers/producers and market controllers.  The research is transformative in its development and use of modeling and simulation tools, tested with real data, to identify security and privacy risks associated with different market structures, security methods, and threat types.

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. electric grid faces the need to rapidly decarbonize while simultaneously supporting the electrification of transportation, heating, and industrial processes.  The large-scale introduction of variable energy sources such as solar and wind power has made it more difficult for utilities to balance supply and demand in real time. One answer to these challenges is the creation of distributed markets in which electricity prices are set through bidding by small producers and consumers. Such markets can respond rapidly to changing local conditions by signaling participants to change their production or consumption on short notice.

However, these markets may also cause the grid to be more vulnerable to cyberattacks. The number of participants and their identities and behavior will be less predictable than in existing markets operating at the transmission level. Relatively unsophisticated traders using equipment and software from a variety of vendors may not take effective security measures. High frequency trading--the very feature that makes distributed markets valuable--may make it difficult for market operators to verify bids in real time when problems are suspected.

Before such markets are widely deployed, the potential risks and impacts of cyberattacks must be better understood and strategies must be developed to mitigate those risks. To that end, this project examined research questions: (1) What are the potential security risks associated with dynamic distributed energy markets? (2) What are the potential impacts of various types of cyberattacks on those markets? (3) What security practices, policies and regulations are needed to minimize risk as the number of traders and frequency of transactions increase? (4) What are the trade-offs between the benefits created by dynamic markets and the costs of securing them?

To address these questions, we developed a computational model capable of simulating a large number of agents interacting in a network of high-frequency distribution-level electricity markets. The agents include legitimate buyers and sellers of electricity; distribution utilities or other parties acting as market makers; and a range of possible adversaries attempting to disrupt the system. Legitimate traders and market makers are connected by a simulated electrical grid that has multiple nodes and includes capacity limits on individual circuits. The model allowed us to simulate a spectrum of cyberattacks ranging from relatively unsophisticated distributed denial-of-service (DOS) attacks to more sophisticated threats involving different strategies on the part of attackers and different levels of protection against those attacks in the form of encryption and other defenses.

The main findings are as follows.  First, even unsophisticated attacks can be disruptive. DOS attacks, for example, can prevent bids from some traders from reaching the market operator during a given bidding period, leading to apparent demand and supply curves that differ from their true values. Because the price that clears the apparent market may differ from the true market-clearing price, the actual demand and supply of electricity may be significantly out of equilibrium.  As DOS attacks increase and a smaller share of legitimate bids get through, this gap can increase and the operator faces greater uncertainty about supply and demand. Other attacks, such as spoofing or man-in-the-middle attacks could also produce inaccurate supply and demand information, resulting in incorrect price signals to buyers and sellers, and would be harder than DOS attacks for the market operator to detect. Any of these cases could lead to outages if there is inadequate transmission capacity to allow electricity to flow from one node to the next, or utilities lack sufficient generation to act as a supplier of last resort.

There are ways to mitigate these risks but each comes with its own costs. One-way and two-way encryption of bids and responses is effective, but is costly and requires proper measures on the part of participants who may lack the knowledge or attention to carry them out. Another solution is for utilities to invest in transmission infrastructure and reserve capacity to cover local imbalances caused by cyberattacks. However, the cost of these investments reduces the economic benefits of operating dynamic markets.  Yet another option is to change the market process, such as by increasing the time from when bidding is closed and when prices are announced, to give the market operator more time to evaluate the number and nature of bids to determine whether an attack is occurring. However, the longer the delay involved, the less rapidly the market can respond to changing grid conditions.

The prototype implementation of the market simulator and adversaries has been made available on GitHub. These can be used by other researchers, as well as practitioners and regulators to simulate a variety of market structures and examine their vulnerabilities to different types of attacks. These tools can be applied through the planning, design, and implementation of dynamic electricity markets to understand and prepare for potential cyber risks and their impacts.
